turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: This is my good John Brown.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I have asked him to show you a little of Highland life while you are with us at Balmoral.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Should we take it seriously?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: The cartoon or Her Majesty's absenteeism?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Well, both.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: The question is, do we need her?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Surely, you're not suggesting we dispense--

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: My dear Stanley, a Prime Minister with only a handful of friends must respect public opinion.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Gossip counts.  Lord Aberdeen was right.  This country is not governed by wisdom but by talk.  Granted, it wouldn't take much to winkle the old girl out of mourning, but if public opinion is against her, then it doesn't do to appear too close.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: We'll see which way the wind blows.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I see the Prince of Wales is here.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I hope he got his mother's permission.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: What did he want?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: To know when he'll be king.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: We're going to lose.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: You can't know that for sure.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Gladstone's got his party facing the same way for the first time in years. We need help.  Where is the old girl?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: Mrs Brown.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: It's questionable whether there's any advantage to be had from that direction.  She's never been less popular.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: In the press, perhaps.  But she's sold more copies of her Highland Journal in three months than Punch will ever sell in a year.  Time to wheel her out.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: She's refusing to leave Balmoral.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: What's her excuse this time?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: The Princess Louisa is too ill to move.  Frankly, the Queen's rather upset at the recent spate of bad publicity.  You're smiling.

turns.speaker: DISRAELI
turns.text: I was trying to imagine "rather upset."

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: A fine choice, sir.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Excellent!

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: A distinct flushing around the cheeks. She was drunk, I tell you.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: No, she wasn't.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Erysipelas.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Not too protracted, I hope.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: A few days...  When he heard, the Prince of Wales threw the bust from the window of the Royal Gallery.  It took four hours to gather the fragments.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: The Queen wishes to publish an account of him.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Dear oh dear.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: We think she can be dissuaded.  Have you had a glance at the diary?

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Quite.  I think I'd best take it back.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Where did you find it by the way?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Some young page was boasting about having seen it.  Lucky.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Well, no rest for the wicked, Henry.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: No, indeed.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: We're expecting Brown this afternoon, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Whom?

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: I'm sorry, ma'am?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Cold is good!

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Excellent, ma'am, excellent.  But perhaps if her Majesty were to consider accompanying her new-found physical vigor with the benefits of mental activity...

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why am I being lectured in this way?!

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty.  In no way did I wish to suggest--

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I will not tolerate anybody lecturing me about the responsibility of the monarchy....

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: No.  You are mistaken.  Prince Albert, my husband, had typhoid fever.  I asked what was wrong with my son.

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: The same, your Majesty.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why was I not informed?

turns.speaker: JENNER
turns.text: I did not consider it wise, in the circumstances, to tax your nerves.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: How ill is he?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: The Royal Family and senior members of the household, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Just them?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: It's Mr Brown, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What is he doing there?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: He appears to be ... standing by his horse.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: I made no request to go out riding today.  How long has he been there?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: I don't know, ma'am.  He was observed earlier, I believe.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: Mr Brown is unable to attend today.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: I believe he is unwell, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Unwell?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: I understand he was in a fight.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Has he been hurt?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: I believe not, ma'am.  I understand -- he'd had rather too much to drink.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: How long has he been this sick?

turns.speaker: LADY ELY
turns.text: A few days, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why was I not told earlier?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Sir Henry, Mr Brown is standing in the courtyard.  I have no wish to go riding.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I'm very sorry, ma'am.  I can't imagine -- he was certainly given no instructions.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Please make sure it does not happen again.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Of course, at once.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Lord Clarendon arrives, by invitation, at eleven o'clock, followed at twelve by a picnic in the grounds to celebrate Princess Alice's birthday. Dispatches, as usual, at two.  The Chancellor writes to say that, by happy coincidence, he will be in Cowes for the weekend.  He asks if Your Majesty might grant him an audience.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: He thought, perhaps, Your Majesty might wish to be informed of the latest developments in government.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: No.  I shall be out walking.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: We stayed a little longer than expected with Mr and Mrs Grant.  It was most agreeable.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: We were expecting you to return by six.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: And now I am back.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Read it.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Again?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Read it!

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Who told them that?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I -- forgive me, ma'am, I am no wiser than yourself.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: No-one should think themselves wiser than me!  It is not for any of the Queen's subjects to presume to tell Her Majesty when and where She should come out of mourning.  It is the Queen's sorrow that keeps her secluded!  It is Her overwhelming amount of work and responsibility, work which She feels will soon wear her out entirely!

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Your Majesty --

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Is it not enough that She is uncheered and unguided that she should also have to suffer these malicious rumors?!  I am not a fool.  I know there are those in the establishment too afraid to attack me and so they attack my dearest friends. Sometimes -- I feel that Brown is all I have left of Albert.  And now they attack Brown too.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: There is one other matter.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: I have a letter, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: From whom?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: From Princess Helena and other members of your family.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: My family is quite capable of communicating with the Queen in person.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What do they want?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: They are demanding the dismissal of John Brown on grounds of drunkeness.

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Ma'am?

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Please tell the Princess, and other signatories to this letter, that the Queen will not be dictated to, or made to alter, in any way, what she has found to answer for her comfort.  Do I make myself clear?

turns.speaker: PONSONBY
turns.text: Ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: That's a very pretty shawl you are wearing, Alex.  Silk suits you well.  But you are not eating enough.  One must not let vanity overrule one's appetite.

turns.speaker: PRINCESS ALEXANDRA
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Where is my son?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS ALEXANDRA
turns.text: Prince Albert is at Windsor, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Why is he not here?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS ALEXANDRA
turns.text: He is sick, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: Then why are you not with him?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS ALEXANDRA
turns.text: You ordered all members of the Royal Family to attend you at Balmoral.

turns.speaker: VICTORIA
turns.text: What is the matter with him?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS ALEXANDRA
turns.text: He has typhoid fever, ma'am.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Does that thing work?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Getting there.  It's more sensitive than a joy-stick.  Your video-character can respond as fast as you can.  But what can I do for you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: It's a tough game.  Hard to pin that bastard down.  Keeps on changing the rules.

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: You've got your ten levels, right? Here they are...  Each level has an exit, only remember, the exits aren't always what they seem.  First one's The Blood Red Sky, then you've got The Blue Desert, Tower of Ghosts, Kingdom of the Blind...  On each world you have to find a golden key and you've only got so much time to do it in.  If you're too late, The Screamer comes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How do you stop The Screamer?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: You can't.  He gets you and you're dead. It's like time catching up with you, you know?  Like Fate.  Each level you get progressively less time to complete.  First half of the game takes place in the Wild Lands.  Then you reach Level 6, and that's the Sea of Darkness.  There's a two-headed Boatman that'll take you across if you answer his riddle right.  If you don't...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What's the riddle?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: If I tell you, then it's no fun.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Just tell me the fucking riddle.

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Well...it involves a paradox.  You have to trick The Boatman.  Now all the while, you also have to watch your strength.  You can build that back up by catching FIREFLIES...the little glowing guys...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How the hell did you do that?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Well, we're veering into classified info here, but I'll tell you that it involved a donor.  He was dead of course, so it's not like anything unethical was happening.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Could you play ARCADE with that?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Well, technically "yes", but this is only the prototype.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Thanks, Albert.  Think you could print up those schematics?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: We're having some problems with ARCADE...

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Yeah, who isn't.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: We vere thinking there might be tricks. You know, surprises that you'd worked into the game...

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Sure.  Every game's got 'em.  I'll start with the schematics.  I can print these up if you want.

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: The next half of the game takes place in ARCADE's brain, The City of Truth. It's urban scenarios, lots of metal and concrete. Screamer comes faster here.  On Level Four you can get a free life if you wait until the last possible second before exiting that world.  Gotta time it right though.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What's the question mark?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Level Ten.  That's where you've got to unlock ARCADE's heart using the keys you've found.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How do you do that?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Good question.  See, that's where the fun comes in.  ARCADE changes it every time. He's a machine without a soul. Once you give him a soul, he stops being a threat.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But how can it change every time?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: It's the game's logic core.  We actually patterned it after human brainwaves.  I mean, there's a personality in there. That's what makes it so incredible.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dead?

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: Well, brain-dead anyway.  Coma patient. It's really not all that important.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Maybe he's not dead.

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: He?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The donor.  Maybe he's alive inside the game.

turns.speaker: ALBERT
turns.text: And maybe you've been taking too many drugs.

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: Nick, Alex, how are we today?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How'd you know it was us?

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: Security camera.  Pulled your files before I came down. Be careful what you say, kids ... I know where you live.

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: Now what seems to be the problem?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It's the game, ARCADE.

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: You don't like it?

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: If this is a joke, I'm not laughing.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Neither are we.  Something's wrong with the game, Mr. Difford.

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: Why don't we take this into my office.

turns.speaker: DIFFORD
turns.text: Talk to me.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: There's something wrong with ARCADE. The game's alive somehow...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: He thinks I'm "sublimating".

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: What the hell does that mean?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Has anyone seen Greg?

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: He's probably outside.  You know how he is. Gets bored...

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: Sick?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Everybody's sick, huh?  It's fifteen after.  We always meet here, you know that.

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: What's her problem?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Did you play ARCADE last night?

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: Actually, no.  I was just telling Nick, here, that my t.v.'s busted...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Liar.  Did you come from the city on the left, or the city on the right?

turns.speaker: STILTS
turns.text: I came from the city on the left.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But you always lie, so you didn't come from there.  That means the city on the left must be the City of Truth.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: So where is he?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Guess he took off...  You have his keys, right?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Hmmm.  He said you were going to have dinner?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: So take his car home.  Wait.  I'm sure he's up to something...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But he was playing the game.  I mean, you saw him...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Hey, kid.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Nick...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Have you played the game yet?  It's incredible!  I was just...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Listen to me!  Greg never came home. I think the game has something to do with it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I have to talk to you.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We are talking...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, in person.  Now.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's twelve-thirty!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm coming over.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Alex, you don't know how long I've waited for this.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Funny.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What do you mean by "weird"?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Greg never came home.  A few hours is one thing, Nick, but this is different. Something's happened to him.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Can you turn off the game?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm in the middle of it...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Turn if off!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Happy?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No.  Look, I know you're not going to believe me, but listen anyway...  I think the game's alive somehow.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, wait.  Just listen.  I hooked it up earlier tonight, and it said my name.  As soon as I turned it on, Nick.  It said my name.  How could it know?  And then, I asked it where Greg was, and it said, "In here".

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Alex, I think you're freaking out. Greg's gone, I'll give you that.  And maybe he's in trouble.  But it's not ARCADE that's doing it...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How?!  It's a machine, Alex. Machine's don't think.  They're not alive.  It's a good program, a brilliant program, it was designed so it would act as if it were alive, but it's not alive.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: So how did it know my name, then?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You imagined it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: See, men always do this.  "Quiet down, honey.  Chill out.  Take a Valium". I'm not a fucking idiot, Nick!  I DID NOT IMAGINE IT!!!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Quiet.  I do have parents, you know.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: It turned itself back on, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No it didn't.  It's just a faulty relay or something.  It happens.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Sorry.  Maybe I need the Valium.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Call the others.  Laurie, Benz...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Something's happened to them.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's the middle of the night.  They're asleep.  Phone didn't wake them.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: All of them?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Because I didn't know where else to go.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's two o'clock in the morning.  Go home. Go to sleep.  We'll figure something out in the morning.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's not this weird.  It'll make sense. Everything gets weird this late anyway, right?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: We have to find out what's happened to them. I think they're gone...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No way.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: If they're sick, great.  But let's make sure.  Come on, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Okay.  We'll see what's up.  But if things are cool, I don't want to hear anything more about this.  Life's too short, know what I mean?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: She thought Benz was at school.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Where to now?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Laurie's.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: This is like a movie or something.  I mean, am I paranoid or what?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It doesn't necessarily mean she's...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Let's go around back.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Change the channel!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Then leave her.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: We can't...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We'll call 911.  Look around Alex.  We broke in, smashed the t.v., no one's going to believe what happened here!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Where do we go?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: My house.  I want to try something.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: That's what I thought.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's not just the cable system.  It's in the phone system as well, the electronic net.  It's everywhere.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Nick, what is it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Maybe it is alive in a way...some sort of electronic intelligence.  It's like a computer virus that developed a personality or something.  It's self-replicating...it mimics life.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Like the fractals?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's growing.  Getting stronger. Maybe it's only localized now...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: ...but then it hits the relay stations...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Right.  And then communication satellites, and then anywhere.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Anywhere.  We have to stop it from getting out.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's already out.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The Police, then...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Give me a break, Alex.  What are we going to tell them?  Excuse me, officer, but there's some sort of electronic monster loose in the phone lines.  I'd think twice about calling any of those 976 numbers...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Then where do we go?!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: SLIP-STREAM.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: They made ARCADE.  It's still a game, right?  It thinks like a game.  Maybe it still has to play by the rules. Someone had to program it in the first place, didn't they?.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You mean we learn the rules...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And beat it at it's own game.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You realize that in order to do that, we'd actually have to play the game.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I was afraid you'd say that.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Virgin sacrifices?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Drives 'em crazy every time.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What Alex is trying to say is that it "seems" like it's alive.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No I'm not...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We're not getting very far into the levels and we kind of thought maybe we could talk to a programmer, learn some tricks and stuff...  I mean, you don't want us kids running around school saying your game's too hard, right?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Go outside, get your car, and meet me out front with the engine running. And make it quick, okay?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Get that helmet.  If we're going to play ARCADE, I want every advantage possible.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I can't believe you made it!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You got the schematics?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Everything.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I've been thinking about that.  ARCADE's like a virus, so it seems like the place to hit him would be where the virus started.  You know, like his point of origin?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Dante's Inferno.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah.  The Inferno.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Alex...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You didn't hear me?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What are you looking for?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: A way to hook this helmet into the game. I'm sure there are interfaces...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't understand.  It wants us to play the game.  It's been taunting us ...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Put in a quarter.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It can turn itself on, Alex!  It doesn't need a quarter.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes it does.  Don't you see?  We have to play by the rules.  That's what it wants.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You're not coming, Alex.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes I am...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I know how to do this!  I'm good at these games.  You never play, you'd be nailed in an instant.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And what if something happens to you? Am I suppose to go in after you alone?!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.  If you're smart, you run like hell.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You don't get it, do you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't want anything to happen to you.  I care about you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I already have a boyfriend, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I know.  It sucks.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You feel it?  It's different this time.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: We're actually inside, aren't we?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Okay.  Give us a kiss?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: One.  In case...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Don't even say it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Thanks.  Always wanted to do that.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yeah, well I figure these are unusual circumstances.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: That's what I was hoping you'd say.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'll take the lead and handle the physical threats.  You watch the elapsed time and look for exits.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Which way do you think Level Two is?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You've got the schematics, check.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Okay.  It's West.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The keys are supposed to be at the end of each level.  Once we get all the keys, we can unlock ARCADE's heart. And then...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The clock's already ticking.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Right, then...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: And we've still got time left.  This was a piece of cake.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yeah, that's what worries me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Hey, my strength's low.  Look out for Fireflies.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: There...

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Shit...

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Check your read-out.
